titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Office Files of Sir Brian Urquhart
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Office Files of Sir Brian Urquhart FA550

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-02-17 10:06:00 -0500.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, International Affairs Program, Office Files of Sir Brian Urquhart

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, meeting records, documentation of writing and regional projects, speaking engagements and events, and united nations studies.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Brian Urquhart is a diplomat, author, and World War II veteran. From 1986 to 1995, he served as a Scholar in Residence in the Ford Foundation's International Affairs Program.

Urquhart served in the British Army during World War II. After his military service, he helped found the United Nations and became the Personal Assistant of Trygve Lie, the first UN Secretary-General. He helped organize and direct the UN's peacekeeping operations in Cyprus, Kashmir, Lebanon, and the Congo. In 1972, he became the UN's Under-Secretary-General for Special Political Affairs. He stayed in that position until he joined the Ford Foundation.
